pain_points_original.title: Ensuring AI Security & Data Privacy Compliance
pain_points_original.description: The DPC must ensure any AI tool strictly adheres to government policies for handling sensitive data. This is critical as they must comply with the "Applicable ICT, Security and Cyber policies" and "South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) Instruction" to safeguard government data.

pain_points_original.title: Boosting Government Efficiency & Service Delivery
pain_points_original.description: The DPC is seeking to overcome operational challenges and improve core functions. The goal is to leverage AI to "boost efficiency, inform decision-making, and drive innovation" which is essential for improving service delivery, increasing public satisfaction, and achieving better community outcomes.

pain_points_original.title: Integrating AI with Existing Government Systems
pain_points_original.description: The DPC faces the technical risk of procuring incompatible or unproven technology. They need to "assess the maturity, scalability, and adaptability of vendor solutions" to ensure they can be successfully integrated with complex, existing government systems without causing disruption.

pain_points_original.title: Navigating the Unproven AI Solutions Market
pain_points_original.description: The DPC lacks a clear understanding of the AI market and its proven applications for government. They need to de-risk procurement by learning from "vendors' experiences in deploying AI solutions within similar sectors" and seeing evidence of successful deployments in a government context.

pain_points_original.title: Unclear AI Costs for Future Budget Planning
pain_points_original.description: The department cannot effectively plan or commit to future AI projects without a clear understanding of the financial investment required. They need "indicative costing models and pricing structures to inform future procurement planning and budget allocation" to proceed with any implementation.
